docs.lead_paragraph: This week’s Supreme Court hearings on the health care law seemed to suggest that some justices were embracing any argument they could use to kill reform.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column holds the Supreme Court's hearings on the health care law seem to suggest the conservative justices were willing to embrace any argument they could to strike down the law; fears the nation's already badly damaged faith in the Supreme Court's ability to stand above politics is about to take another severe hit.
docs.snippet: This week’s Supreme Court hearings on the health care law seemed to suggest that some justices were embracing any argument they could use to kill reform.

headline.main: Life, Interrupted: Facing Cancer in Your 20s

docs.abstract: After my diagnosis of cancer, I moved back into my childhood bedroom so my parents could take care of me. At the same time, I’ve had no choice but to grow up fast, writes Suleika Jaouad in a new weekly column chronicling her experiences as a young cancer patient.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group led by Magic Johnson agreed to buy the Dodgers for $2.15 billion, gambling that a new cable TV deal in 2013 will make the gigantic outlay worthwhile.

headline.seo: Dodgers’ Huge Price Tag Is Tied to TV Windfall
headline.main: A Team’s Huge Price Tag Is Tied to a TV Windfall
headline.print_headline: A Team’s Huge Price Tag Is Tied to a TV Windfall

docs.abstract: Analysis holds that in agreeing to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers for $2.15 billion, the group led by Magic Johnson is gambling that a new cable TV deal in 2013 will make the gigantic outlay worthwhile.
docs.snippet: A group led by Magic Johnson agreed to buy the Dodgers for $2.15 billion, gambling that a new cable TV deal in 2013 will make the gigantic outlay worthwhile.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the last day of hearings for the Obama administration’s health care reform, conservative justices were asking policy questions that seemed beyond their constitutional role.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes the discourse of conservative Supreme Court justices during their review of the Affordable Care Act; contends their questions were political and partisan rather than constitutional; opposes argument offered by Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony Kennedy that the entire law should be overturned if the court rules against its individual mandate provision.
docs.snippet: On the last day of hearings for the Obama administration’s health care reform, conservative justices were asking policy questions that seemed beyond their constitutional role.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: For all of the fretting by liberals and legal analysts, it is certain there will be substantial political repercussions over the ruling on the Obama health care overhaul.

headline.seo: Whatever the Ruling in Health Case, Bipartisan Fallout
headline.main: Parties Brace for Fallout in Court’s Ruling on Health Care

docs.abstract: Political Memo; Both Mitt Romney and Pres Obama face tricky political paths in light of the Supreme Court's constitutional review of the health care law; White House must publicly defend the law’s constitutionality and push back against suggestions that the battle is already lost, even as they privately piece together a contingency plan if the law--or part of it--is overturned when the court rules in June.
docs.snippet: For all of the fretting by liberals and legal analysts, it is certain there will be substantial political repercussions over the ruling on the Obama health care overhaul.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Three days of debate over the health care overhaul seemed to reinforce what many Americans believed about it, but with an extra dose of repulsion or delight.

headline.seo: Health Care Debate Ripples Across U.S. as Hearings End
headline.main: Few Minds Are Changed by Arguments in Court
headline.print_headline: Few Minds Are Changed By Arguments in Court

docs.abstract: Three days of sharp debate in the Supreme Court over the fate of the Affordable Care Act seems to have reinforced what many Americans already believe about the health care overhaul, as opponents enjoy what seems a largely negative tone among the court's conservative justices; some supporters fear law may be overturned when the court rules in June.
docs.snippet: Three days of debate over the health care overhaul seemed to reinforce what many Americans believed about it, but with an extra dose of repulsion or delight.
